I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based  grant  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  subprogram  2  of  the  Investment  Climate 
Improvement  Program.1 The  report  also  describes  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  preparing 
subprogram 3 of the Investment Climate Improvement Program, and if the Board approves the 
proposed grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.2 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
2.  With almost a third of its 5.6 million people living in poverty, the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
economic growth  and  investment  have  been  low  and  unstable.  Growth  of gross  domestic 
product (GDP) averaged 4.1% since 2002, fluctuating from –1.4% to 8.5%. Gross fixed capital 
formation increased from 16.4% of GDP in 2005 to 25.3% in 2011, but its growth was volatile. 
The country has attracted foreign investment, but mainly in gold mining, which generates little 
employment. The official unemployment rate was 7.8% in 2011, but actual unemployment may 
be much higher. Low growth rates and economic instability were mainly caused by weaknesses 
in  the  business  environment,  combined  with  internal  and  external  shocks.  These  included 
political turmoil in 2005 and 2010,3 and spillover from the global crisis in 2008–2009, mainly 
through Kazakhstan and the Russian Federation. Insufficient economic diversification makes 
the economy of the Kyrgyz Republic particularly vulnerable to shocks. 
3.  With the investment climate and despite past reforms, private enterprises still suffer from 
excessive regulatory and licensing requirements, pervasive inspections by various enforcement 
agencies, complex and arbitrary taxation, and cross-border trade barriers such as complex pre-
customs clearance. These, with the room for corruption and fraud they create,4 constrain most 
private enterprises, especially women entrepreneurs’ smaller businesses. Remaining policy, 
legal, and regulatory issues restrict access to finance, particularly for micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises and women entrepreneurs, who frequently have little collateral to offer for 
cultural reasons. Inadequate worker skills are an increasingly pressing issue, as the education 
system  responds  poorly  to  changing  market  needs  and  many  qualified  workers  seek 
employment abroad. Labor migrants’ remittances reached 25% of GDP in 2010, but they fuel 
consumption rather than investment and increase imports, as the weak business environment 
prevents many enterprises from positively responding to demand by increasing production and 
employment.  Finally,  weaknesses  in  the  education  and  health  systems  and  inadequate 
infrastructure  in  other  sectors  frequently  result  from  underinvestment.  A  weak  enabling 
environment has been preventing private investment in these areas. Due to fiscal weakness, the 
Kyrgyz Republic is in particular need of such investment.  
4.  There is broad consensus that the long-term development prospects of the Kyrgyz 
Republic depend on its ability to improve its investment climate to develop a vibrant private 
sector,  diversify  the  economy,  and  expand  markets.  This  would  make  the  economy  more 
resilient, promote long-term growth, create additional employment, and help reduce poverty.

5.  The Investment Climate Improvement Program, approved by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in 2008, follows a programmatic approach and envisages three subprograms to 
assist the government in creating conditions for sustainable economic growth and employment-
generating investments.5 Subprogram 1, implemented in 2007–2008, included a policy-based 
grant,  a  project  grant  supporting  the  development  of  information  technology  systems  for 
effective implementation of reforms, and a TA grant to help prepare subprogram 2. Preparation 
and  implementation  of  subprogram 2  has  also  benefited  from  and  reinforced  other 
interventions.6 The reforms supported under subprogram 2 build on the achievements made 
under subprogram 1 despite difficult political and external conditions. They address binding 
constraints to private sector development and diversification in the areas of business regulation 
and taxation, access to finance, worker skills development, and public–private partnerships 
(PPPs). The relevance of these constraints has been confirmed through recent studies and 
surveys,  which  explain  some  deviations  from  the  constraints  originally  identified  in  2008. 
Subprogram 2 is effectively gender mainstreamed to maximize benefits to women. The reform 
agenda that remains after subprogram 2 will be addressed under subprogram 3.  
6.  Subprogram 2 complements the efforts of (i) ADB and other development partners to 
strengthen  physical  infrastructure  and  improve  access to finance;  and  (ii)  the International 
Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  to  rebuild fiscal  buffers and  safeguard  monetary  stability,  which  are 
important for a healthy business and investment climate.7 
7.  Improving the investment climate for the private sector is critical for the government’s 
economic growth policies.8 Subprogram 2 contributes toward this end. The Government of the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  emphasizes  improving  the  business  climate.9 ADB’s  country  operations 
business plan for the Kyrgyz Republic identifies subprogram 2 as a means of broadening the 
Kyrgyz economy and its private sector.10 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of subprogram 2 will be sustainable economic growth and employment 
creation. The outcome will be an improved business environment and investment climate.

10.  Output 1: Cost of regulatory compliance reduced. Subprogram 2 has reduced the 
regulatory costs of operating a business and made regulatory action more transparent and 
accountable. This has also helped reduce the scope for fraud and corruption.

4 
11.  Specifically, under subprogram 2, the government has simplified business registration by 
streamlining  preregistration  requirements,  acceding to the  Hague  Apostille  Convention  that 
abolishes the requirement of legalization for foreign public documents, establishing one-stop 
registration shops in all regions of the Kyrgyz Republic, and allowing electronic submission of 
documents. The latter is particularly important for entrepreneurs in remote areas, which are 
often rural women. The government has also reduced tax compliance costs and scope for 
informal payments by simplifying tax forms and the profit tax system for small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs), and introducing one-stop windows for taxpayers and electronic filing of tax 
returns.  
12.  Following a regulatory impact assessment,11 licenses have been reduced by more than 
20%.  The  number  of  licenses  can  be  further  reduced  and  their  validity  extended  under 
subprogram  3.  Furthermore,  the  government  has  introduced  the  concept  of  risk-based 
inspections, which prioritizes firms with higher risk of noncompliance, instead of targeting all 
firms. This approach helps use scarce regulatory capacity more efficiently, reduce compliance 
cost,  and  minimize  corruption.  The  number  of  inspection  agencies  will  be  reduced  under 
subprogram  3.  Finally,  under  subprogram  2,  a  pilot  system  for  pre-customs  clearing  was 
initiated  to  facilitate  compliance  with  cross-border  trade  rules.  The  system  automates  the 
exchange of information between government bodies involved in pre-customs clearance, and 
the submission of documents to customs. 
13.  As a deviation from indicative actions included in the policy matrix for subprogram 2 in 
2008, subprogram 2 is not supporting deregistration of dormant companies, because it was not 
reconfirmed as a key binding constraint for the private sector. Further, ISO 9001 confirmation for 
the one-stop business registration process has not been included given its time and resource 
requirements. Instead, subprogram 2 has reduced tax compliance costs, as outlined above.  
14.  Output  2:  Access  to  finance  improved.  Subprogram  2  has  addressed  structural 
impediments to lending by promoting alternative financial products and strengthening nonbank 
financing sources, including microfinance organizations (MFOs). This will benefit SMEs and 
microenterprises—particularly women entrepreneurs, who account for 75% of MFO borrowers. 
15.  Under subprogram 2, the government has improved creditor rights and  the dispute 
resolution framework by enabling accelerated court enforcement of arbitral awards to reduce 
foreclosure  costs.  Online  filing  of  pledges  and  payment  of  fees  will  be  enabled  under 
subprogram 3. To help mitigate credit risks, the National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic (NBKR), 
as regulator, has institutionalized incentives for financial institutions to share credit information 
by strengthening self-regulation of the credit bureau. The bureau now requires members to 
check credit histories of loan applicants and report credit events, while the NBKR is supervising 
compliance. As an alternative to loans, the government has promoted financial leasing by 
removing tax disadvantages compared to other borrowing instruments. Leasing may be very 
attractive for women who present a good credit risk but often cannot offer collateral. To increase 
the availability of financial services, the NBKR is enabling MFOs to serve their clients better by 
extending  the  scope  of  their  services  beyond  loans  and  leasing.  The  NBKR  has  also 
streamlined regulatory requirements for term deposits to improve the funding availability of 
MFOs, and clarified the process and requirements for the transformation of MFOs into deposit-
taking banks. This will allow larger MFOs to grow with their clients’ needs. The NBKR has also 
enabled group lending to be classified as secured lending for banks’ prudential requirements; 
this will remove a specific transformation constraint and benefit borrowers without collateral.

D.  Development Financing Needs 
20.  The government has requested a policy-based grant not exceeding $20 million from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance subprogram 2.17 Grant proceeds will be made 
available for withdrawal in a single tranche upon grant effectiveness. All policy actions included 
in the policy matrix of subprogram 2 have been complied with (Appendix 4). The local currency 
funds generated by the grant will finance the government’s development expenditure program.  
21.  The grant size is justified in light of the overall development finance needs of the Kyrgyz 
Republic. The government has embarked on a process of fiscal consolidation under an IMF-
supported program with the aim to reduce public debt from 62.6% of GDP in 2010 to 55.1% in 
2014. The state budget for 2012 foresees expenditure of Som115.8 billion (or $2.5 billion). This 
is  equivalent  to  about  38.4%  of  forecast  GDP,  down  from  39.7%  in  2011.  However,  the 
government plans to keep capital expenditure at the same level as in 2011 at about 7.0% of 
GDP, given its importance for growth.18 The planned budget deficit for 2012 is equivalent to 
6.7% of GDP, down from 7.6% in 2011. The government does not have access to international 
capital markets. Domestic deficit financing is still restricted by the legacy of the recent global 
crisis, which hit banks and securities markets in the Kyrgyz Republic particularly hard. Deficit 
financing, thus, mainly depends on access to concessional funds from abroad. Without these 
funds, capital expenditure would have to be cut substantially, which would decelerate GDP 
growth and potentially undermine social and political stability. The proposed grant of $20 million 
is equivalent to 0.3% of the Kyrgyz Republic’s GDP, 4.3% of capital expenditure, and 4.5% of 
the budget deficit in 2012. The grant will, as such, make a small but important contribution to 
meeting the country’s financing needs. The budget support committed by the World Bank for 
2012 is of similar magnitude. The disbursements planned by the IMF in 2012 are slightly higher 
at 0.4% of GDP.

benefit from an improved legal and regulatory environment. Subprogram 2 has also indirectly 
benefited the working age population, as investment opportunities translate into job creation 
and/or  better  wages.  By  reducing  regulatory  costs,  subprogram  2  has  attracted  more 
businesses into the formal sector, thus increasing the number of formal jobs and, potentially, tax 
revenues. The students of vocational schools and clients of financial service providers have also 
benefited  from  subprogram  2.  Because  of  economies  of  agglomeration,  investment  and   
employment opportunities are expected to be concentrated in urban areas. Nonetheless, the 
rural population has still benefited from an improved business climate and better access to 
financial services.

34.  Budget planning and execution, and fiduciary controls have been assessed through a 
public expenditure and financial accountability assessment undertaken in 2009,28 and a public

35.  2010–2011 was a period of political volatility and change in the Kyrgyz Republic, which 
created additional challenges for public financial management, including high staff turnover and 
frequent policy changes, but also great opportunities. Governance had substantially deteriorated 
in the years before the ouster of President Bakiev in April 2010. Since a provisional government 
was  established,  important  positive  changes  included  introducing  management  information 
systems,  automating  tax  and  custom  operations,  modernizing  treasury  operations,  and 
decentralizing some financial management functions to local governments. Subprogram 2 has 
made an important contribution by supporting deregulation and automation. However, because 
of social unrest and economic volatility, the predictability of revenues and, in turn, budget 
planning and execution remained key public financial management issues. The new President 
was elected in October 2011 and inaugurated in December. Subsequently, a new coalition 
government was elected by Parliament. A higher degree of political stability than in 2010–2011 
can be expected in the foreseeable future.

38.  A recent survey indicates that firms in the Kyrgyz Republic are more likely to have full-
time female workers and female participation in ownership than firms in most other countries in 
Eastern Europe and Central Asia (footnote 27). However, stereotypes and patriarchal views of 
women’s role in society continue to limit women’s ability to develop businesses. Men are almost 
three times more likely to engage in full-time entrepreneurial activities than women or to identify 
themselves  as  self-employed.  Main  constraints  are  limited  access  to  affordable  financial 
services, limited skills, and registration systems that make it difficult for women to establish 
formal businesses. Moreover, data about women business ownership are limited, which makes 
it  difficult to  design  targeted  support  policies. Under  subprogram  2, MFOs  will  be  able  to 
broaden their services and reduce funding cost, which will disproportionally benefit women, who 
account for 75% of MFO clients. Support for leasing and group lending under subprogram 2 will 
also benefit creditworthy women, who often cannot offer collateral. The automated business 
registration creates sex-disaggregated data and will allow monitoring and analysis of female 
business ownership. Finally, the NPSDC includes representatives from two organizations that 
represent the interests of women entrepreneurs, so that the voice of women can be heard when 
deciding on skills development. Subprogram 2 is, therefore, categorized as effective gender 
mainstreaming.
